Regularization for Shuffled Data Problems via Exponential Family Priors on the Permutation Group


Zhenbang Wang∗
Emanuel Ben-David†
Martin Slawski∗

∗Department of Statistics, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA 22030, USA    
†Center for Statistical Research and Methodology (CSRM), U.S. Census Bureau, Suitland, MD 20746, USA
zwang39@gmu.edu     emanuel.ben.david@census.gov     mslawsk3@gmu.edu.

Abstract

In the analysis of data sets consisting of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y)-pairs, a tacit assumption is that each pair corresponds to the same observation unit. If, however, such pairs are obtained via record linkage of two files, this assumption can be violated as a result of mismatch error rooting, for example, in the lack of reliable identifiers in the two files. Recently, there has been a surge of interest in this setting under the term “Shuffled data” in which the underlying correct pairing of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y)-pairs is represented via an unknown index permutation. Explicit modeling of the permutation tends to be associated with substantial overfitting, prompting the need for suitable methods of regularization. In this paper, we propose a flexible exponential family prior on the permutation group for this purpose that can be used to integrate various structures such as sparse and locally constrained shuffling. This prior turns out to be conjugate for canonical shuffled data problems in which the likelihood conditional on a fixed permutation can be expressed as product over the corresponding (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y)-pairs. Inference is based on the EM algorithm in which the intractable E-step is approximated by the Fisher-Yates algorithm. The M-step is shown to admit a significant reduction from n2superscript𝑛2n^{2} to n𝑛n terms if the likelihood of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y)-pairs has exponential family form as in the case of generalized linear models. Comparisons on synthetic and real data show that the proposed approach compares favorably to competing methods.

1 Introduction

Shuffled data problems refer broadly to situations in which the goal is to perform inference for a functional of the joint distribution of a pair of random variables (𝐱,𝐲)𝐱𝐲(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}) (such as, e.g., their covariance) based on separate samples {𝐱i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and {𝐲i}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑖1𝑚\{\mathbf{y}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m} that involve matching pairs {(Xπ∗​(i),Yi)}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑋superscript𝜋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖𝑖1𝑚\{(X_{\pi^{*}(i)},Y_{i})\}_{i=1}^{m} pertaining to the same statistical unit, where the map π∗:{1,…,m}→{1,…,n}:superscript𝜋→1…𝑚1…𝑛\pi^{*}:\{1,\ldots,m\}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,n\} may only be observed incompletely. This is a rather common scenario in data integration problems in which different pieces of information about a shared set of entities reside in multiple data sources that need to be combined in order to perform a given data analysis task. The process of identifying matching parts across two or more files is often far from trivial in the absence of unique identifiers, and has thus grown into a vast and active field of research known as record linkage (e.g., [1]). The above shuffled data model in terms of the unknown map π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} represents a direct approach to account for mismatches in record linkage and their impact on downstream data analysis. Historically, shuffled data problems were first systematically discussed in a series of papers by DeGroot et al. [2, 3, 4, 5], with little to no progress until only a few years ago given advances in computation [6]. Recently, shuffled data problems have generated much more widespread interest, fueled by novel applications in engineering and computer vision, among others [7, 8, 9]. Several papers have investigated the statistical limits of signal estimation and permutation recovery in unlabeled sensing in which the goal is to recover a signal θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} from n𝑛n noisy linear measurements yi=⟨𝐱π∗​(i),θ∗⟩+ϵisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝐱superscript𝜋𝑖superscript𝜃subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖y_{i}=\langle\mathbf{x}_{\pi^{*}(i)},\theta^{*}\rangle+\epsilon_{i}, 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n, where π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is an unknown index permutation [7, 8, 10, 11, 12]. Another line of research has studied similar permuted data settings in which x𝑥x and y𝑦y are scalar and related by a monotone transformation [13, 14, 15, 16, 17].

A common conclusion from these works is that shuffled data problems are generally plagued by both statistical and computational challenges. First, the combinatorial nature of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} makes it hard to devise computationally tractable approaches with provable guarantees. Existing algorithmic “solutions” involve integer programming [12, 18, 19] and the EM algorithm [20, 21, 6]. Regardless of the computational challenges, shuffled data problems tend to be highly susceptible to noise and prone to overfitting. In fact, statistical guarantees typically involve unrealistically stringent signal-to-noise requirements [8, 10, 22]. Loosely speaking, this issue results from the fact that the set of index permutations grows rapidly in size with n𝑛n. This observation suggests that suitable forms of regularization hinging on prior information on π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} are needed to constrain the size of the parameter space under consideration. Several papers consider partial shufflings in which varying fractions of (𝐱i,𝐲i)subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i})-pairs are already observed with the correct correspondence [22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27], and only the remaining portion of the data is subject to shuffling. Another constraint commonly encountered in record linkage applications is that π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is block-structured with known composition of the blocks based on auxiliary variables that are required to agree for matching records [28, 29, 30]. In other applications such as signal processing and computer vision, π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is often constrained to act locally in the sense that indices are shuffled only within small time windows or image regions [31, 32].

The goal of the present paper is the development of a regularization framework for shuffled data problems that integrates the aforementioned as well as potential other constraints in a unified fashion. For this purpose, we introduce an exponential family prior on the permutation group that is flexible enough to accommodate any kind of prior information that can be expressed in terms of index pairs (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). Conveniently, this prior turns out to be conjugate for canonical shuffled data problems in which the likelihood conditional on a fixed permutation can be expressed as the product over the corresponding (𝐱,𝐲)𝐱𝐲(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})-pairs. Inference is performed via the Monte-Carlo EM algorithm considered in earlier works [33, 21, 6]. We show that for exponential family likelihoods, the resulting M-step is particularly scalable since it only involves n𝑛n instead of n2superscript𝑛2n^{2} terms. Moreover, computation of the MAP estimator of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} with the remaining parameters fixed is shown to reduce to a linear assignment problem (LAP), and hence remains computationally tractable. Several theoretical results as well as a collection of experiments for various shuffled data settings demonstrate the usefulness of regularization based on the proposed prior in comparison to the unregularized counterpart and several other baselines. Paper organization. Section §§\S2 starts with a detailed motivation of the proposed approach, followed by a discussion of central technical and computational aspects. Section §§\S3 contains several theoretical results and accompanying discussions. Numerical results on synthetic and real data are presented in §§\S4. Proofs and complementary technical details are relegated to the appendix.

Conventions. We often refer to a permutation via the underlying map π𝜋\pi and the corresponding matrix ΠΠ\Pi in an interchangeable fashion, and accordingly 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n) and subsets thereof may refer to both maps and matrices. Asterisked symbols such as π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}, θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*}, σ∗subscript𝜎\sigma_{*} etc. refer to ground truth parameters, whereas non-asterisked symbols such as π𝜋\pi, θ𝜃\theta, σ𝜎\sigma etc. refer to generic elements of the associated parameter spaces.

2 Approach

The following three subsections are dedicated to a detailed account of the approach. We start with a brief motivation before a more formal systematic introduction and subsequent technical details pertaining to computation and model fitting.

2.1 Motivating examples

Consider the simple linear regression setup yi=xπ∗​(i)​β∗+σ∗​ϵisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥superscript𝜋𝑖superscript𝛽subscript𝜎subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖y_{i}=x_{\pi^{*}(i)}\beta^{*}+\sigma_{*}\epsilon_{i}, where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} and ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} are independent standard normal random variables, 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n, and π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} permutes 10% of the indices uniformly at random. Suppose that the sign of β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} is known to be positive. Then the ML estimator of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} (or equivalently, the MAP estimator under a uniform prior over 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n)) is given by the permutation π^MLsubscript^𝜋ML\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}} that matches the corresponding order statistics in {xi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and {yi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, i.e.,

∑i=1nxπ^ML​(i)​yi=∑i=1nx(i)​y(i)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥subscript^𝜋ML𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}}(i)}y_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{(i)}y_{(i)} (1)

As shown in Figure 1, the estimator π^MLsubscript^𝜋ML\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}} performs rather poorly. The scatterplot of the matching of corresponding order statistics is far from that of the underlying correct pairing. In fact, π^MLsubscript^𝜋ML\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}} is associated with massive overfitting as made explicit in the sequel. Let

denote the resulting ML estimators of β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} and σ∗2superscriptsubscript𝜎2\sigma_{*}^{2}, respectively. It is straightforward to show that

β^ML→(β∗)2+σ∗2,σ^ML2→0,1n​∑i=1n(xi​β∗−xi​β^ML)2→σ∗2formulae-sequence→subscript^𝛽MLsuperscriptsuperscript𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜎2formulae-sequence→superscriptsubscript^𝜎ML20→1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝛽subscript𝑥𝑖subscript^𝛽ML2superscriptsubscript𝜎2\widehat{\beta}_{\text{ML}}\rightarrow\sqrt{(\beta^{*})^{2}+\sigma_{*}^{2}},\qquad\widehat{\sigma}_{\text{ML}}^{2}\rightarrow 0,\qquad\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}\beta^{*}-x_{i}\widehat{\beta}_{\text{ML}})^{2}\rightarrow\sigma_{*}^{2} (2)

in probability as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty (see Appendix A for a derivation). In particular, the second and third relation in (2) are alarming since they imply that the least squares fit absorbs all the noise.

Figure 1 shows that the ML estimator is too aggressive in forming “corrected” pairs (xπ^ML​(i),yi)subscript𝑥subscript^𝜋ML𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(x_{\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}}(i)},y_{i}) given that only 10% of the observations are actually mismatched, and among those 10%, only a similarly small fraction contributes substantial mismatch that visibly exceeds the noise inherent in the problem. Sparsity of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is often a reasonable assumption in post-linkage data analysis (e.g., [28, 29, 22, 24]), where sparsity here refers to the set of mismatches {1≤i≤n:π∗​(i)≠i}conditional-set1𝑖𝑛superscript𝜋𝑖𝑖\{1\leq i\leq n:\pi^{*}(i)\neq i\} having significantly smaller cardinality than n𝑛n. If an upper bound on the number of mismatches, say k𝑘k, is known, it is appropriate to consider the following constrained ML estimator of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}:

maxπ∈𝒫​(n)​∑i=1nxπ​(i)​yisubject to​dH​(π,id)≤k,subscript𝜋𝒫𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝜋𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subject tosubscript𝑑H𝜋id𝑘\max_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{\pi(i)}y_{i}\quad\text{subject to}\;d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id})\leq k, (3)

where id is the identity map on [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n] and dH​(π,π′)=∑i=1n𝕀​(π​(i)≠π′​(i))subscript𝑑H𝜋superscript𝜋′superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝕀𝜋𝑖superscript𝜋′𝑖d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\pi^{\prime})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{I}(\pi(i)\neq\pi^{\prime}(i)) denotes the Hamming distance between two elements π,π′𝜋superscript𝜋′\pi,\pi^{\prime} of 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n). For k=n𝑘𝑛k=n, the maximizer of the above problem is given by π^MLsubscript^𝜋ML\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}} and for k<2𝑘2k<2, the maximizer is given by id. For general k𝑘k, to the best of our knowledge, there is no efficient algorithm for computing the maximizer directly. However, there exists a Lagrangian multiplier γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 such that (3) is equivalent to the optimization problem

maxπ∈𝒫​(n)⁡{∑i=1nxπ​(i)​yi−γ​dH​(π,id)}=maxΠ∈𝒫​(n)⁡{∑i=1n∑j=1nπi​j​(xj​yi−γ​𝕀​(i≠j))},subscript𝜋𝒫𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝜋𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝛾subscript𝑑H𝜋idsubscriptΠ𝒫𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝛾𝕀𝑖𝑗\max_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{\pi(i)}y_{i}-\gamma d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id})\right\}=\max_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\pi_{ij}(x_{j}y_{i}-\gamma\mathbb{I}(i\neq j))\right\}, (4)

which is a linear assignment problem with cost matrix C=(γ​𝕀​(i≠j)−xj​yi)i,j𝐶subscript𝛾𝕀𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖𝑗C=\big{(}\gamma\mathbb{I}(i\neq j)-x_{j}y_{i}\big{)}_{i,j}, which is computationally tractable according to the discussion following (7) below. As elaborated in the next subsection §§\S2.2, the maximizer of (4) corresponds to the MAP estimator of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} (for fixed model parameter β𝛽\beta) under a specific class of prior distributions over 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n). The right panel of Figure 1 highlights the improvement that can be achieved by the resulting estimator which here only performs a small number of re-pairings capturing those pairs that correspond to massive mismatch error in the left panel. This re-pairing is consistent with the underlying regression slope, avoiding both the amplification bias associated with π^MLsubscript^𝜋ML\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}} depicted in the middle panel as well as the attenuation bias that is incurred when ignoring mismatch error altogether (e.g., [34, 35, 36, 37]) .

Figure 2 illustrates scenarios in which π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is not sparse (with a mismatch rate exceeding 80%), but constrained to be a “local shuffling” in the sense that maxi∈[n]⁡|π∗​(i)−i|≤rsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝜋𝑖𝑖𝑟\max_{i\in[n]}|\pi^{*}(i)-i|\leq r, i.e., the corresponding permutation matrix is a band matrix with bandwidth at most r𝑟r. This scenario is particularly relevant when the data is recorded sequentially (e.g., over different time points) or across a spatial domain endowed with a notion of distance, and it is known that π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} can only mix up the order of data inside a specific time window or within a local neighborhood. There are numerous applications in which π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is locally constrained such as genome sequencing [11], signal processing [38, 32], or computer vision [31].

The illustrative example in Figure 2 can be thought of as a regression problem in which the signal is a sine with known frequency but unknown (positive) amplitude β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*}, i.e., yti=β∗​sin⁡(10​π​ti)+0.1​ϵisubscript𝑦subscript𝑡𝑖superscript𝛽10𝜋subscript𝑡𝑖0.1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖y_{t_{i}}=\beta^{*}\sin(10\pi t_{i})+0.1\epsilon_{i}, 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n (left panel). However, the observed data is of the form (ytπ∗​(i))i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦subscript𝑡superscript𝜋𝑖𝑖1𝑛(y_{t_{\pi^{*}(i)}})_{i=1}^{n} for some unknown (local) permutation π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} (middle panel). If β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} is known to be positive, then the (unconstrained) ML estimator π^MLsubscript^𝜋ML\widehat{\pi}_{\text{ML}} of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} matches the order statistics {μ(i)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{\mu_{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{n} and {y(i)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{y_{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{n}, where μi=sin⁡(10​π​ti)subscript𝜇𝑖10𝜋subscript𝑡𝑖\mu_{i}=\sin(10\pi t_{i}), 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n. In order to improve over the ML estimator using the prior knowledge of local shuffling, we impose the constraint that the alternative estimator π^^𝜋\widehat{\pi} does not pair any indices that are more than r=3𝑟3r=3 apart. This estimator can be obtained as solution of the optimization problem

maxπ∈𝒫​(n)maxi∈[n]⁡|π​(i)−i|≤r⁡{∑i=1nμi​yπ​(i)}=maxΠ∈𝒫​(n)⁡{∑i=1n∑j=1nπi​j​(μi​yj−ci​j)},subscript𝜋𝒫𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝜋𝑖𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑦𝜋𝑖subscriptΠ𝒫𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗\max_{\begin{subarray}{c}\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)\\ \max_{i\in[n]}|\pi(i)-i|\leq r\end{subarray}}\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mu_{i}y_{\pi(i)}\right\}=\max_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\pi_{ij}(\mu_{i}y_{j}-c_{ij})\right\}, (5)

where ci​j=0subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗0c_{ij}=0 if |i−j|≤r𝑖𝑗𝑟|i-j|\leq r and ci​j=+∞subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗c_{ij}=+\infty otherwise. As in (4), the problem on the right hand side is a linear assignment problem and hence computationally tractable, and corresponds to MAP estimation under the family of priors considered below in detail. The corrected, i.e., repaired data (ti,yπ^∘π∗​(i))i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑦^𝜋superscript𝜋𝑖𝑖1𝑛(t_{i},y_{\widehat{\pi}\circ\pi^{*}(i)})_{i=1}^{n} based on this approach are depicted in the right panel of Figure 2.

2.2 Exponential family prior on 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n)

In this subsection, we show that the priors discussed in the two examples of the previous subsection can be understood as specific instances of a more general family of prior distributions over 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n). Specifically, we consider the family of priors

p​(π)∝exp⁡(γ​tr​(Π⊤​M)),M∈ℝn×n,γ>0,formulae-sequenceproportional-to𝑝𝜋𝛾trsuperscriptΠtop𝑀formulae-sequence𝑀superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛𝛾0p(\pi)\propto\exp(\gamma\,\mathrm{tr}(\Pi^{\top}M)),\quad M\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n},\quad\gamma>0, (6)

where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is the concentration parameter, and the matrix M𝑀M (which is not required to have any specific properties) defines the mode(s) of the distribution, i.e., argmaxΠ∈𝒫​(n)⟨Π,M⟩subscriptargmaxΠ𝒫𝑛Π𝑀\operatorname*{argmax}_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\langle\Pi,M\rangle, where ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle here represents the trace inner product on matrices of the same dimension that induces the Frobenius norm ∥⋅∥Fsubscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅F\lVert\cdot\rVert_{\textsf{F}}. In the same vein, the mode(s) of the distribution correspond to the set of matrices closest to M𝑀M with respect to the same norm. Moreover, the distribution specified by (6) is of exponential family form with respect to the trace inner product (cf., e.g., §§\S3.2 in [39]). Linear Assignment Problems. Linear Assignment problems (LAPs) are a well-studied class of optimization problems for computing optimal one-to-one matchings of two sets of items [40]. LAPs are of the form

minΠ∈𝒫​(n)⁡⟨Π,C⟩,subscriptΠ𝒫𝑛Π𝐶\min_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\langle\Pi,C\rangle, (7)

where C𝐶C is a given cost matrix. By the Birkhoff-von Neumann theorem [41], the vertices of the set of n𝑛n-by-n𝑛n doubly stochastic matrices

𝒟​𝒮​(n)={P∈ℝn×n:Pi​j≥0, 1≤i,j≤n,∑j=1nPi​j=1,  1≤i≤n,∑i=1nPi​j=1,  1≤j≤n}𝒟𝒮𝑛conditional-set𝑃superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗0formulae-sequence1𝑖formulae-sequence𝑗𝑛formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗11𝑖𝑛formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗11𝑗𝑛\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}(n)=\left\{P\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}:\;P_{ij}\geq 0,\;1\leq i,j\leq n,\;\sum_{j=1}^{n}P_{ij}=1,\;\,1\leq i\leq n,\;\sum_{i=1}^{n}P_{ij}=1,\;\,1\leq j\leq n\right\}

are given by 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n). As a result, the minimum over 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n) can be replaced by the minimum over 𝒟​𝒮​(n)𝒟𝒮𝑛\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}(n), hence (7) reduces to a linear program in n2superscript𝑛2n^{2} variables and n2+2​nsuperscript𝑛22𝑛n^{2}+2n linear constraints.

This brief summary entails that computing a mode of (6) reduces to a tractable problem, by setting C=−M𝐶𝑀C=-M in (7).

Specific examples. Below, we consider a few examples of interest that are special cases of (6). (I) Hamming prior.
Consider the choice M=In𝑀subscript𝐼𝑛M=I_{n}. In this case, for any Π∈𝒫​(n)Π𝒫𝑛\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n), we have

⟨Π,In⟩=∑i=1nΠi​i=n−∑i=1n𝕀​(Πi​i≠1)=n−dH​(π,id),Πsubscript𝐼𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptΠ𝑖𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝕀subscriptΠ𝑖𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑑H𝜋id\langle\Pi,I_{n}\rangle=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Pi_{ii}=n-\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{I}(\Pi_{ii}\neq 1)=n-d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id}),

where, as before, dH​(π,π′)=∑i=1n𝕀​(π​(i)≠π′​(i))subscript𝑑H𝜋superscript𝜋′superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝕀𝜋𝑖superscript𝜋′𝑖d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\pi^{\prime})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{I}(\pi(i)\neq\pi^{\prime}(i)) denotes the Hamming distance on 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n). Since n𝑛n does not depend on π𝜋\pi, this implies that (6) can be expressed equivalently as

p​(π)∝exp⁡(−γ​dH​(π,id)),proportional-to𝑝𝜋𝛾subscript𝑑H𝜋idp(\pi)\propto\exp(-\gamma\,d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id})), (8)

which appeared in the first example of the preceding subsection §§\S2.1, cf. (4), in which the goal was to take into account the underlying low rate of mismatches. The distribution (8) is a specific instance of the class of Mallow’s priors of the form p​(π)∝exp⁡(−γ​d​(π,π0))proportional-to𝑝𝜋𝛾𝑑𝜋subscript𝜋0p(\pi)\propto\exp(-\gamma d(\pi,\pi_{0})) for a base permutation π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0} and a metric d𝑑d on 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n) [42, 43, 44, 45, 46]. We note, however, that the family of Mallow’s priors is not a sub-family of the exponential family prior (6) since the metric d𝑑d cannot be expressed via a trace inner product in general. (II) Local shuffling prior.
As in the second example in §§\S2.1, suppose we want to have the prior p𝑝p place most of its mass on permutations that move indices within small windows, i.e., |π​(i)−i|𝜋𝑖𝑖|\pi(i)-i| tends to be small. This can be achieved by choosing the entries of the matrix M𝑀M in (6) of the form Mi​j=−ϕ​(|i−j|)subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗italic-ϕ𝑖𝑗M_{ij}=-\phi(|i-j|) for some non-decreasing function ϕ:ℝ+→ℝ+:italic-ϕ→subscriptℝsubscriptℝ\phi:\mathbb{R}_{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}. The choice ϕ​(u)=0italic-ϕ𝑢0\phi(u)=0 if u≤r𝑢𝑟u\leq r for some positive integer r𝑟r and ϕ​(u)=+∞italic-ϕ𝑢\phi(u)=+\infty otherwise yields the approach (5) that underlies the example in Figure 2 above. (III) Block prior.
Under the local shuffling assumption maxi∈[n]⁡|π∗​(i)−i|≤rsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝜋𝑖𝑖𝑟\max_{i\in[n]}|\pi^{*}(i)-i|\leq r, the corresponding permutation matrix Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*} is typically block diagonal, i.e., Π∗=bdiag​(Π1∗,…,ΠB∗)superscriptΠbdiagsuperscriptsubscriptΠ1…subscriptsuperscriptΠ𝐵\Pi^{*}=\text{bdiag}(\Pi_{1}^{*},\ldots,\Pi^{*}_{B}), with all B𝐵B blocks having size proportional to r𝑟r. Note that the composition of the blocks is generally not known in advance. On the other hand, in record linkage applications, it is rather common that the composition of the blocks is indeed known given matching variables used during record linkage. For example, suppose that the combination of gender, ethnicity, and age group are used for that purpose and that these three categorical variables are free of errors. In this case, mismatches can only involve pairs (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) falling into the same block corresponding to a specific combination of gender, ethnicity, and age. Such known block structure can be encoded via prior (6) by choosing Mi​j=−∞subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗M_{ij}=-\infty if (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) is not contained in the same block and Mi​j=0subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗0M_{ij}=0 otherwise. Note that this corresponds to a uniform prior for each block, i.e., p​(π)=∏b=1Bp​(πb)𝑝𝜋superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑏1𝐵𝑝subscript𝜋𝑏p(\pi)=\prod_{b=1}^{B}p(\pi_{b}) with p​(πb)∝1proportional-to𝑝subscript𝜋𝑏1p(\pi_{b})\propto 1, 1≤b≤B1𝑏𝐵1\leq b\leq B. The prior for each block does not have to be necessarily uniform. For example, a Hamming prior as in Example (I) above can be used instead. Moreover, the hard block constraint can be softened by choosing a suitable finite negative number for entries Mi​jsubscript𝑀𝑖𝑗M_{ij} corresponding to pairs (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) not contained in the same block. (IV) Lahiri-Larsen prior.
In their seminal work on adjusting (generalized) linear regression in the presence of mismatch errors, Lahiri & Larsen [47] and Chambers [28] assume that π∗∼p​(π)similar-tosuperscript𝜋𝑝𝜋\pi^{*}\sim p(\pi) whose expectation 𝐄p​(π)⁡[Π∗]=Qsubscript𝐄𝑝𝜋superscriptΠ𝑄\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{p(\pi)}[\Pi^{*}]=Q is known to the (post-linkage) data analyst. Observe that Q∈𝒟​𝒮​(n)𝑄𝒟𝒮𝑛Q\in\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}(n) is a double stochastic matrix. Any distribution over permutations whose expectation equals Q𝑄Q can be used as a potential prior. In fact, it is known that there are distributions supported over only O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}) (as opposed to n!𝑛n!) permutations satisfying that requirement. Identification of the support via Birkhoff’s decomposition [48] requires at least O​(n4)𝑂superscript𝑛4O(n^{4}) runtime, and hence is not scalable. In the framework considered here, it is convenient to use M=Q𝑀𝑄M=Q in the prior (7). The mode(s) of that prior are then given by the permutation matrices solving the Euclidean projection problem minΠ∈𝒫​(n)∥Π−Q∥F2\min_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\lVert\Pi-Q\rVert_{\textsf{F}}^{2} of Q𝑄Q on 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n). A basic example for Q𝑄Q results for the so-called exchangeable linkage model in [28, 30] in which Q=(1−α)​In+αn−1​𝟏n​𝟏n⊤𝑄1𝛼subscript𝐼𝑛𝛼𝑛1subscript1𝑛superscriptsubscript1𝑛topQ=(1-\alpha)I_{n}+\frac{\alpha}{n-1}\bm{1}_{n}\bm{1}_{n}^{\top}. Since in this case ⟨Q,Π⟩=(1−α)​⟨In,Π⟩+α​nn−1𝑄Π1𝛼subscript𝐼𝑛Π𝛼𝑛𝑛1\left\langle Q,\Pi\right\rangle=(1-\alpha)\left\langle I_{n},\Pi\right\rangle+\alpha\frac{n}{n-1} for α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1), the resulting prior is equivalent to the Hamming prior considered in Example (I). More complex priors are obtained depending on the structure of Q𝑄Q.

2.3 Integration in Shuffled Data Problems

In this subsection, we outline how the above prior can be integrated into generic shuffled data problems. The proposed Monte-Carlo EM [49] framework builds upon the classical work [33] that has been rediscovered in the more recent work [21]. The Monte-Carlo EM scheme in [33] was further developed based on the concept of data augmentation [50] in Gutman et al. [6]. Note that none of [33, 21, 6] consider informative priors for the permutation. Conditional and Integrated Likelihood Suppose we are given data 𝒟={(𝐱i,𝐲i)}i=1n𝒟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathcal{D}=\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{n} potentially contaminated by mismatch error. Let p​(𝐱j,𝐲i;θ)𝑝subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝐲𝑖𝜃p(\mathbf{x}_{j},\mathbf{y}_{i};\theta) be the likelihood (depending on a parameter θ𝜃\theta) for the pairing of 𝐱jsubscript𝐱𝑗\mathbf{x}_{j} with 𝐲isubscript𝐲𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i}, (i,j)∈[n]2𝑖𝑗superscriptdelimited-[]𝑛2(i,j)\in[n]^{2}. The likelihood for θ𝜃\theta resulting from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} conditional on a specific permutation π∈𝒫​(n)𝜋𝒫𝑛\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n) is given by

L​(θ|π)=∏i=1np​(𝐱π​(i),𝐲i;θ)=∏i=1n∏j=1np​(𝐱j,𝐲i;θ)πi​j𝐿conditional𝜃𝜋superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛𝑝subscript𝐱𝜋𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝑛𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝐲𝑖𝜃subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗L(\theta|\pi)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}p(\mathbf{x}_{\pi(i)},\mathbf{y}_{i};\theta)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\prod_{j=1}^{n}p(\mathbf{x}_{j},\mathbf{y}_{i};\theta)^{\pi_{ij}} (9)

Conjugacy. It is worth noting that under (9), the posterior p​(π|𝒟,θ)𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟𝜃p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta) is a member of the family of distributions specified by p​(π)𝑝𝜋p(\pi) of the form (6), i.e., the latter is a conjugate prior. This follows immediately from the observation that

p​(π|𝒟,θ)∝p​(𝒟|π,θ)⋅p​(π)proportional-to𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟𝜃⋅𝑝conditional𝒟𝜋𝜃𝑝𝜋\displaystyle p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta)\propto p(\mathcal{D}|\pi,\theta)\cdot p(\pi) =L​(θ|π)⋅p​(π)absent⋅𝐿conditional𝜃𝜋𝑝𝜋\displaystyle=L(\theta|\pi)\cdot p(\pi)
=exp⁡(∑i=1n∑j=1nπi​j​[log⁡{p​(𝐱j,𝐲i|θ)}+γ​Mi​j])absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑝subscript𝐱𝑗conditionalsubscript𝐲𝑖𝜃𝛾subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=\exp\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\pi_{ij}\left[\log\{p(\mathbf{x}_{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}|\theta)\}+\gamma M_{ij}\right]\right)
=exp⁡(tr​(Π⊤​M𝒟,θ,γ)),absenttrsuperscriptΠtopsubscript𝑀𝒟𝜃𝛾\displaystyle=\exp(\mathrm{tr}(\Pi^{\top}M_{\mathcal{D},\theta,\gamma})), (10)

with M𝒟,θ,γ=(log⁡(p​(𝐱j,𝐲i|θ))+γ​Mi​j)subscript𝑀𝒟𝜃𝛾𝑝subscript𝐱𝑗conditionalsubscript𝐲𝑖𝜃𝛾subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗M_{\mathcal{D},\theta,\gamma}=\big{(}\log(p(\mathbf{x}_{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}|\theta))+\gamma M_{ij}\big{)}.

The (conditional) likelihood (9) can be maximized with respect to both θ𝜃\theta and π𝜋\pi as, e.g., in [8, 11, 22]. In an alternative view, θ𝜃\theta is considered as the quantity of primary interest, in which case one would rather consider the integrated likelihood

L​(θ)=𝐄π⁡[L​(θ|π)]=∑π∈𝒫​(n)L​(θ|π)​p​(π).𝐿𝜃subscript𝐄𝜋𝐿conditional𝜃𝜋subscript𝜋𝒫𝑛𝐿conditional𝜃𝜋𝑝𝜋L(\theta)=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{\pi}[L(\theta|\pi)]=\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}L(\theta|\pi)p(\pi). (11)

As seen in §§\S2.1, maximizing the conditional likelihood tends to be prone to overfitting, prompting a need for regularization. The use of the integrated likelihood mitigates that problem at best slightly, but not substantially as can be seen, e.g., by examining the case of linear regression with i.i.d. Gaussian errors (cf. Appendix E), hence regularization remains relevant. Monte Carlo EM scheme The Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm [51] is an established heuristic for (approximately) minimizing the negative log-likelihood corresponding to (11). Specifically, instead of minimizing ℓ​(θ)=−log⁡L​(θ)ℓ𝜃𝐿𝜃\ell(\theta)=-\log L(\theta), a sequence of surrogate functions {ℓ~(t)​(θ;θ(t))}t≥0subscriptsuperscript~ℓ𝑡𝜃superscript𝜃𝑡𝑡0\{\widetilde{\ell}^{(t)}(\theta;\theta^{(t)})\}_{t\geq 0} are minimized successively:

ℓ(θ)=−log𝐄π[L(θ|π)]↝𝐄π|𝒟,θ(t)[−logL(θ|π)]=:ℓ~(t)(θ;θ(t)),\ell(\theta)=-\log\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{\pi}[L(\theta|\pi)]\;\;\leadsto\;\;\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}}[-\log L(\theta|\pi)]=\mathrel{\mathop{:}}\widetilde{\ell}^{(t)}(\theta;\theta^{(t)}),

where

𝐄π|𝒟,θ(t)⁡[−log⁡L​(θ|π)]=∑i=1n∑j=1n𝐄⁡[πi​j|𝒟,θ(t)]​{−log⁡p​(𝐱j,𝐲i;θ)}subscript𝐄conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡𝐿conditional𝜃𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛𝐄conditionalsubscript𝜋𝑖𝑗𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡𝑝subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝐲𝑖𝜃\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}}[-\log L(\theta|\pi)]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\pi_{ij}|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]\{-\log p(\mathbf{x}_{j},\mathbf{y}_{i};\theta)\} (12)

is the so-called expected complete data negative log-likelihood. The surrogates {ℓ~(t)​(⋅;θ(t))}superscript~ℓ𝑡⋅superscript𝜃𝑡\{\widetilde{\ell}^{(t)}(\cdot\,;\theta^{(t)})\} tend to be easier to minimize since they are linear combinations of standard likelihood terms as they are encountered for fixed and known π𝜋\pi. Surrogates are updated according to the recursion

θ(t+1)←argminθℓ~(t)​(θ;θ(t))↝ℓ~(t+1)​(θ;θ(t+1)).←superscript𝜃𝑡1subscriptargmin𝜃superscript~ℓ𝑡𝜃superscript𝜃𝑡leads-tosuperscript~ℓ𝑡1𝜃superscript𝜃𝑡1\theta^{(t+1)}\leftarrow\operatorname*{argmin}_{\theta}\widetilde{\ell}^{(t)}(\theta;\theta^{(t)})\;\;\leadsto\;\;\widetilde{\ell}^{(t+1)}(\theta;\theta^{(t+1)}).

It can be shown [51] that the sequence generated in this fashion exhibits a monotonic descent property with respect to the original objective ℓℓ\ell, i.e., ℓ​(θ(t+1))≤ℓ​(θ(t))ℓsuperscript𝜃𝑡1ℓsuperscript𝜃𝑡\ell(\theta^{(t+1)})\leq\ell(\theta^{(t)}) for all t𝑡t.

Here, the main challenge of this scheme is the E-step, i.e, the calculation of the expectation on the right term in (12). For any entry πi​jsubscript𝜋𝑖𝑗\pi_{ij} of ΠΠ\Pi, we have

𝐄⁡[πi​j|𝒟,θ(t)]=∑π∈𝒫​(n)p​(π|𝒟,θ(t))​πi​j𝐄conditionalsubscript𝜋𝑖𝑗𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜋𝒫𝑛𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\pi_{ij}|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]=\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)})\pi_{ij} ∝∑π∈𝒫​(n)p​(𝒟|π,θ(t))​p​(π)​πi​jproportional-toabsentsubscript𝜋𝒫𝑛𝑝conditional𝒟𝜋superscript𝜃𝑡𝑝𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\propto\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}p(\mathcal{D}|\pi,\theta^{(t)})p(\pi)\pi_{ij}
=∑π∈𝒫​(n){∏i=1np​(𝐱π​(i),𝐲i;θ(t))}​p​(π)​πi​j.absentsubscript𝜋𝒫𝑛superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛𝑝subscript𝐱𝜋𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡𝑝𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\left\{\prod_{i=1}^{n}p(\mathbf{x}_{\pi(i)},\mathbf{y}_{i};\theta^{(t)})\right\}p(\pi)\pi_{ij}.

Since the summation over 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n) is not computationally tractable, the expectation needs to be approximated, e.g., via Monte Carlo simulation. Since for the same reason, the posterior p​(π|𝒟,θ(t))𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) is only accessible up to an unknown constant (cf. (10)), it is appropriate to resort to Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling techniques [52]. The Metropolis-Hastings (MH) algorithm can be used to generate a Markov Chain {π(k)}k≥1subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑘𝑘1\{\pi^{(k)}\}_{k\geq 1} whose stationary distribution equals p​(π|𝒟,θ(t))𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}). This yields the approximation

𝐄^​[πi​j|𝒟,θ(t)]=1m−b​∑k=b+1mπi​j(k),(i,j)∈[n]2.formulae-sequence^𝐄delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝜋𝑖𝑗𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡1𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑏1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑖𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑗superscriptdelimited-[]𝑛2\widehat{\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}}[\pi_{ij}|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]=\frac{1}{m-b}\sum_{k=b+1}^{m}\pi_{ij}^{(k)},\quad(i,j)\in[n]^{2}. (13)

where b𝑏b denotes the length of the so-called “burn-in” period after which the Markov Chain is considered to have reached stationarity, and m𝑚m denotes the total length of the Markov chain. Substituting (13) into (12) then yields what is known as Monte-Carlo EM scheme, summarized in Algorithm 1.

Conveniently, there is a proposal distribution for the MH algorithm that is, in a sense, canonical and easy to work with. That proposal distribution, known as Fisher-Yates sampling, generates a new permutation from the current one by swapping the assignments of a pair of indices (cf. Algorithm 2 for details). Initialization. It is a well-known fact that the choice of the initial iterate θ(0)superscript𝜃0\theta^{(0)} can critically impact the quality of the solution that is returned by EM schemes given that the latter is a local strategy that finds a stationary point of a (in general) non-convex objective near the initial iterate. Several consistent initial estimators of θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} are known for regression setups depending on the structure of π𝜋\pi [22, 24, 47, 28, 29, 23], and those naturally lend themselves as initial iterate for the above EM scheme.

Careful initialization of the MH subroutine is important as well in order to ensure that p​(π|𝒟,θ(t))𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) is explored reasonably well given that the domain of interest 𝒫​(n)𝒫𝑛\mathcal{P}(n) has n!𝑛n! elements while the number of MCMC iterations m𝑚m is limited. Fortunately, under the prior (6), computing the mode argmaxπp​(π|𝒟,θ(t))subscriptargmax𝜋𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡\operatorname*{argmax}_{\pi}p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) reduces to an LAP of the form (7) in virtue of (10). Initialization via the mode has the advantage that the Markov chain is started in a high density region. The hope is that the resulting iterates (which are generated according to a localized proposal distribution) will pick up most of the mass of p​(π|𝒟,θ(t))𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) so that (13) will well approximate the underlying expectation.

Reduction under exponential family likelihood Interestingly, for a variety of exponential family models, the expected complete data negative log-likelihood (12) involves only n𝑛n instead of n2superscript𝑛2n^{2} terms, which is a substantial reduction. Specifically, (12) will be of the form

∑i=1nr{𝐱i,𝐲i,(𝐄[Π|𝒟,θ(t)]⊤𝐘)i;θ)}\sum_{i=1}^{n}r\{\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i},(\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\Pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]^{\top}\mathbf{Y})_{i};\theta)\}

for a function r𝑟r depending at most on {𝐱i,𝐲i,(𝐄[Π|𝒟,θ(t)]⊤𝐘)i}i=1n\{\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i},(\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\Pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]^{\top}\mathbf{Y})_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}. Specific examples of interest are presented in the sequel.(i) Least squares regression. Computational complexity We here discuss the computational complexity of Algorithm 1. For exponential family models benefiting from the above reduction, the M-step, i.e., the update of θ𝜃\theta only involves n𝑛n terms, and is hence computationally equivalent to a standard estimation problem. Apart from the initialization of the Markov chain, the approximate E-step has complexity O​(m)𝑂𝑚O(m), where m𝑚m denotes the length of the Markov chain. Computing the acceptance probability, updating π(k)superscript𝜋𝑘\pi^{(k)}, and keeping tracking of 𝐄^​[Π|𝒟,θ(t)]⊤​𝐘^𝐄superscriptdelimited-[]conditionalΠ𝒟superscript𝜃𝑡top𝐘\widehat{\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}}[\Pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]^{\top}\mathbf{Y} within Algorithm 2 can be done in time O​(1)𝑂1O(1) given that the proposal distribution only changes π(k)superscript𝜋𝑘\pi^{(k)} at two positions. However, m𝑚m is recommended to be at least of the order Ω​(n)Ω𝑛\Omega(n), heuristically justified by the fact that in the worst case a permutation is the product of n−1𝑛1n-1 transpositions. Obtaining the initial permutation π^initsubscript^𝜋init\widehat{\pi}_{\text{init}} generally involves the solution of a linear assignment problem, which is costly with a complexity of O​(n3)𝑂superscript𝑛3O(n^{3}), while approximate solutions via Sinkhorn iterations can be obtained in complexity O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}) [53]. Alternatively, since computing π^initsubscript^𝜋init\widehat{\pi}_{\text{init}} based on an LAP is expensive, π^initsubscript^𝜋init\widehat{\pi}_{\text{init}} can be initialized as the last state of the Markov chain returned by Algorithm 2 in the previous EM iteration t𝑡t, for all EM iterations beyond the first. Data augmentation Following [50] and [6], the Monte-Carlo EM approach can be converted into a Bayesian inference procedure targeting the posterior p​(θ|𝒟)𝑝conditional𝜃𝒟p(\theta|\mathcal{D}), and along the way also p​(π|𝒟)𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟p(\pi|\mathcal{D}). Since Monte-Carlo EM already involves sampling from the distribution of p​(π|𝒟,θ)𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟𝜃p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta), one can as well sample from p​(θ|𝒟,π)𝑝conditional𝜃𝒟𝜋p(\theta|\mathcal{D},\pi) in an alternating fashion, which can be understood as a specific Gibbs sampler for the joint posterior p​(θ,π|𝒟)𝑝𝜃conditional𝜋𝒟p(\theta,\pi|\mathcal{D}). Such sampling scheme is particularly attractive whenever it is easy to sample from p​(θ|𝒟,π)𝑝conditional𝜃𝒟𝜋p(\theta|\mathcal{D},\pi). This is the case, e.g., for the Gaussian linear regression setting with conjugate priors for the regression parameter β𝛽\beta and the error variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, as well as for the precision matrix estimation problem for multivariate Normal data described above with an inverse Wishart prior for ΩΩ\Omega. Compared to the Monte-Carlo EM approach, sampling from p​(θ|𝒟,π)𝑝conditional𝜃𝒟𝜋p(\theta|\mathcal{D},\pi) has potential advantages from the standpoint of inference (approximate standard errors and construction of credibility intervals). An illustrative example is presented in §§\S4.

Beyond permutations We would like to point out that the framework presented herein does not require π𝜋\pi to be a permutation. Specifically, we may be given two separate files 𝒟𝐱={𝐱i}i=1Nsubscript𝒟𝐱superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖1𝑁\mathcal{D}_{\mathbf{x}}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N} and 𝒟𝐲={𝐲i}i=1nsubscript𝒟𝐲superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathcal{D}_{\mathbf{y}}=\{\mathbf{y}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, N>n𝑁𝑛N>n (without loss of generality), and the consider maps π:{1,…,n}→{1,…,N}:𝜋→1…𝑛1…𝑁\pi:\{1,\ldots,n\}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,N\} with corresponding matrix Π∈{0,1}n×NΠsuperscript01𝑛𝑁\Pi\in\{0,1\}^{n\times N} with row sums equal to one. Letting 𝒫​(n,N)𝒫𝑛𝑁\mathcal{P}(n,N) denote the set of all such matrices/maps, we can define a prior of the form (6) given a mode M∈ℝn×N𝑀superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁M\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times N}. Conditional and integrated likelihoods can be defined analogously to (9) and (11), and the conjugacy property (10) continues to hold. The proposed computational Monte-Carlo EM scheme remains applicable with minor modifications in Algorithm 2, inclusive the reduction for exponential family likelihoods.

3 Theoretical Insights

In this section, we present some analysis on the proposed prior from the perspective of regularization. The main purpose of the analysis is to provide additional guidance on the choice of the concentration parameter γ𝛾\gamma in regression problems. Hamming prior. Our first results concerns the MAP estimator of Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*} under the Hamming prior (8). Specifically, we consider the linear regression setup

yi=μπ∗​(i)​(𝐱)+σ∗​ϵi,μi​(𝐱)=𝐱i⊤​β∗,𝐱i∼N​(0,Id),1≤i≤n,{ϵi}i=1n​∼i.i.d.​N​(0,1),formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜇superscript𝜋𝑖𝐱subscript𝜎subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑖𝐱superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖topsuperscript𝛽formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝐱𝑖𝑁0subscript𝐼𝑑1𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑖1𝑛i.i.d.similar-to𝑁01y_{i}=\mu_{\pi^{*}(i)}(\mathbf{x})+\sigma_{*}\epsilon_{i},\quad\mu_{i}(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top}\beta^{*},\quad\mathbf{x}_{i}\sim N(0,I_{d}),1\leq i\leq n,\quad\{\epsilon_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}\overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim}N(0,1), (14)

as considered in a series of prior works on shuffled linear regression [8, 11, 10, 22]. The statement below considers the sparse setting with the underlying permutation π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} satisfying the constraint dH​(π∗,id)≤ksubscript𝑑Hsuperscript𝜋id𝑘d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi^{*},\textsf{id})\leq k for k𝑘k “small enough” as made precise below. Moreover, it is assumed for simplicity that β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} and σ∗2superscriptsubscript𝜎2\sigma_{*}^{2} are known; a variety of estimators for the regression parameter in this scenario have been proposed in the literature [24, 27, 22, 23]. We recall from §§\S2.1 that SNR = ∥β∗∥22/σ∗2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽22superscriptsubscript𝜎2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}^{2}/\sigma_{*}^{2} denotes the signal-to-noise ratio.

Theorem 1.

Suppose the setting (14) holds true. Let Π^^Π\widehat{\Pi} denote the resulting MAP estimator of Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*} with dH​(Π∗,In)≤ksubscript𝑑HsuperscriptΠsubscript𝐼𝑛𝑘d_{\emph{{H}}}(\Pi^{*},I_{n})\leq k. Then, if γ≥3​γ0𝛾3subscript𝛾0\gamma\geq 3\gamma_{0}, where γ0=72​SNR​log⁡(e​n/k)subscript𝛾072SNR𝑒𝑛𝑘\gamma_{0}=72\sqrt{\emph{{SNR}}}\log(en/k), the following holds:

dH​(Π^,In)≤2​k,∥(Π^−Π∗)​𝝁∥2≤σ∗​(17​k​log⁡(e​n/3​k)+2​γ).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑H^Πsubscript𝐼𝑛2𝑘subscriptdelimited-∥∥^ΠsuperscriptΠ𝝁2subscript𝜎17𝑘𝑒𝑛3𝑘2𝛾d_{\emph{{H}}}(\widehat{\Pi},I_{n})\leq 2k,\qquad\lVert(\widehat{\Pi}-\Pi^{*})\bm{\mu}\rVert_{2}\leq\sigma_{*}\left(17\sqrt{k\log(en/3k)}+\sqrt{2\gamma}\right).

with probability at least 1−2/n12𝑛1-2/n and 1−3/n13𝑛1-3/n, respectively, where 𝛍=(μi​(𝐱))i=1n𝛍superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝐱𝑖1𝑛\bm{\mu}=(\mu_{i}(\mathbf{x}))_{i=1}^{n}.

Let us briefly comment on the implications of Theorem 1. First, if γ𝛾\gamma is chosen larger than the threshold γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0}, the MAP estimator Π^^Π\widehat{\Pi} will be 2​k2𝑘2k-sparse, which matches the sparsity of Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*} up to the factor 222. In particular, the triangle inequality implies that dH​(Π∗,Π^)≤3​ksubscript𝑑HsuperscriptΠ^Π3𝑘d_{\textsf{H}}(\Pi^{*},\widehat{\Pi})\leq 3k, i.e., Π^^Π\widehat{\Pi} and Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*} will be close with respect to the Hamming distance. Moreover, for values γ𝛾\gamma such that 3​γ0≤γ≤C​γ03subscript𝛾0𝛾𝐶subscript𝛾03\gamma_{0}\leq\gamma\leq C\gamma_{0} for some constant C>3𝐶3C>3, we obtain that

∥(Π^−Π∗)​𝝁∥2≲σ∗​(k​log⁡(e​n/k)+SNR1/4​k​log⁡(e​n/k)),less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptdelimited-∥∥^ΠsuperscriptΠ𝝁2subscript𝜎𝑘𝑒𝑛𝑘superscriptSNR14𝑘𝑒𝑛𝑘\lVert(\widehat{\Pi}-\Pi^{*})\bm{\mu}\rVert_{2}\lesssim\sigma_{*}(\sqrt{k\log(en/k)}+\textsf{SNR}^{1/4}\sqrt{k\log(en/k)}),

where ≲less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim is short for ≤\leq up to constant factors. The dependence on the signal-to-noise ratio SNR is improved compared to the naive estimator Π^0=Insubscript^Π0subscript𝐼𝑛\widehat{\Pi}_{0}=I_{n}, which will scale as σ∗​k​log⁡(e​n/k)​SNR1/2subscript𝜎𝑘𝑒𝑛𝑘superscriptSNR12\sigma_{*}\sqrt{k\log(en/k)}\textsf{SNR}^{1/2}; note that for small SNR, one cannot hope for improvements over Π^0subscript^Π0\widehat{\Pi}_{0} in general. On the other hand, in light of the discussion in §§\S2.1, the improvement over the maximum likelihood estimator Π^MLsubscript^ΠML\widehat{\Pi}_{\text{ML}} whose corresponding error scales as σ∗​nsubscript𝜎𝑛\sigma_{*}\sqrt{n}, is rather substantial as long as k𝑘k is small relative to n𝑛n. Theorem 1 provides guidance on the choice of γ𝛾\gamma for a specific setup. To an extent, the next result yields a lower bound on γ𝛾\gamma in order to ensure a pre-scribed level of sparsity k𝑘k.

Proposition 1.

Suppose that π𝜋\pi follows the Hamming prior p𝑝p (8) with parameter γ𝛾\gamma. Then for all 2≤k<n2𝑘𝑛2\leq k<n

𝐏π∼p⁡(dH​(π,id)≥k)​{≤exp⁡(−k​δ​log⁡n)if​γ≥(1+δ)​log⁡n,δ>0,≥c​(k,n)if​γ≤log⁡(n−k),subscript𝐏similar-to𝜋𝑝subscript𝑑H𝜋id𝑘casesabsent𝑘𝛿𝑛formulae-sequenceif𝛾1𝛿𝑛𝛿0absent𝑐𝑘𝑛if𝛾𝑛𝑘\operatorname{\mathbf{P}}_{\pi\sim p}\big{(}\text{\emph{$d_{\textsf{H}}$}}(\pi,\textsf{\emph{id}})\geq k\big{)}\begin{cases}\leq\exp(-k\delta\log n)\quad&\text{if}\;\gamma\geq(1+\delta)\log n,\;\delta>0,\\[4.30554pt] \geq c(k,n)\quad&\text{if}\;\gamma\leq\log(n-k),\end{cases}

where c​(k,n)→14​!kk!c(k,n)\rightarrow\frac{1}{4}\frac{!k}{k!} as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty, with !k!k denoting the number of derangements of k𝑘k elements (i.e., the number of permutations without fixed point).

Suppose it is known that dH​(π∗,id)≤ksubscript𝑑Hsuperscript𝜋id𝑘d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi^{*},\textsf{id})\leq k. Then Proposition 1 asserts that the concentration parameter γ𝛾\gamma of the Hamming prior (8) should be chosen proportional to log⁡(n−k)∼log⁡nsimilar-to𝑛𝑘𝑛\log(n-k)\sim\log n as n𝑛n gets large in order to ensure that the prior places essentially no mass outside the Hamming ball {π:dH​(π,id)≤k}conditional-set𝜋subscript𝑑H𝜋id𝑘\{\pi:\,d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id})\leq k\}. The threshold γ∼log⁡nsimilar-to𝛾𝑛\gamma\sim\log n is sharp in the sense that if γ≤log⁡(n−k)𝛾𝑛𝑘\gamma\leq\log(n-k), the prior will place at least constant mass 14!​k/k!∼14​esimilar-to14𝑘𝑘14𝑒\frac{1}{4}!k/k!\sim\frac{1}{4e} for not too small k𝑘k outside that Hamming ball. The likelihood p​(𝒟|π)𝑝conditional𝒟𝜋p(\mathcal{D}|\pi) will favor permutations giving best fit to the observed data, so that the posterior mass 𝐏π|𝒟⁡({π:dH​(π,id)≤k})subscript𝐏conditional𝜋𝒟conditional-set𝜋subscript𝑑H𝜋id𝑘\operatorname{\mathbf{P}}_{\pi|\mathcal{D}}(\{\pi:\,d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id})\leq k\}) will generally be less than the prior mass. Consequently, it is natural to consider the lower bound γ∼log⁡nsimilar-to𝛾𝑛\gamma\sim\log n as a starting point when setting this parameter. Local shuffling prior. The next proposition addresses scenarios similar to that depicted in Figure 2 when the underlying function is Lipschitz continuous. Specifically, the level of penalty that is needed for the MAP solution to satisfy the bandwidth condition |π^​(i)−i|≤r^𝜋𝑖𝑖𝑟|\widehat{\pi}(i)-i|\leq r for all 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n is provided.

Proposition 2.

Suppose that yi=μπ∗​(i)+σ∗​ϵisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜇superscript𝜋𝑖subscript𝜎subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖y_{i}=\mu_{\pi^{*}(i)}+\sigma_{*}\epsilon_{i}, 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n, with {ϵi}i=1n​∼i.i.d.​N​(0,1)superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑖1𝑛i.i.d.similar-to𝑁01\{\epsilon_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}\overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim}N(0,1), where μi=f∗​(i/n)subscript𝜇𝑖superscript𝑓𝑖𝑛\mu_{i}=f^{*}(i/n), 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n for a function f∗:[0,1]→ℝ:superscript𝑓→01ℝf^{*}:[0,1]\rightarrow\mathbb{R} that is L𝐿L-Lipschitz. Let further the matrix M𝑀M in the prior (6) have entries Mi​j=I​(|i−j|≤r)subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗𝐼𝑖𝑗𝑟M_{ij}=I(|i-j|\leq r), 1≤i,j≤nformulae-sequence1𝑖𝑗𝑛1\leq i,j\leq n, for a given bandwidth r=max1≤i≤n⁡|π∗​(i)−i|𝑟subscript1𝑖𝑛superscript𝜋𝑖𝑖r=\max_{1\leq i\leq n}|\pi^{*}(i)-i|. If γ>2​Lσ∗​(log⁡n+2​r)𝛾2𝐿superscript𝜎𝑛2𝑟\gamma>\frac{2L}{\sigma^{*}}\left(\sqrt{\log n}+\sqrt{2}r\right), the resulting MAP estimator π^^𝜋\widehat{\pi} satisfies |π^​(i)−i|≤r^𝜋𝑖𝑖𝑟|\widehat{\pi}(i)-i|\leq r, 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n, with probability at least 1−exp⁡(−(2−1)2/2)−2/n1superscript21222𝑛1-\exp(-(\sqrt{2}-1)^{2}/2)-2/n. In particular, under the same event, max1≤i≤n⁡|μπ^​(i)−μπ∗​(i)|≤2​L⋅r/nsubscript1𝑖𝑛subscript𝜇^𝜋𝑖subscript𝜇superscript𝜋𝑖⋅2𝐿𝑟𝑛\max_{1\leq i\leq n}|\mu_{\widehat{\pi}(i)}-\mu_{\pi^{*}(i)}|\leq 2L\cdot r/n.

Note that while in theory, the assertion of the above proposition can always be achieved by setting γ=∞𝛾\gamma=\infty, established solvers of linear assignment problems require the entries of the cost matrix to be finite. In addition, solver accuracy can degrade with the magnitude of the entries [54].

4 Experiments

In this section, we present the results of experiments conducted with synthetic and real data. At the end of the section, we also show an example demonstrating the use of the data augmentation approach discussed at the end of §§\S2.3 as an alternative to the Monte-Carlo EM scheme. We fix n=1,000𝑛1000n=1,000, d=20𝑑20d=20, σ∗=1subscript𝜎1\sigma_{*}=1, ρ∗=0.8subscript𝜌0.8\rho_{*}=0.8, p=q=5𝑝𝑞5p=q=5, B=50𝐵50B=50. The mismatch rates k/n𝑘𝑛k/n and k⋅B/n⋅𝑘𝐵𝑛k\cdot B/n in (15)(i) and (15)(iii), respectively, are varied between 0.20.20.2 and 0.50.50.5 in steps of 0.050.050.05, and the bandwidth r𝑟r in (15)(ii) is varied between 333 and 101010. For each setup and each value of k𝑘k and r𝑟r, 100 independent replications are performed.

The following approaches are compared:

(I) naive. Standard maximum likelihood estimation as used for parameter estimation in the absence of mismatches, which corresponds to fixing π=id𝜋id\pi=\textsf{id} as the identity permutation. (II) oracle. The unknown permutation π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is considered as known, and standard maximum likelihood estimation is used for parameter estimation after fixing π=π∗𝜋superscript𝜋\pi=\pi^{*}. (III) robust [for setting k𝑘k-Sparse only]. For setup LR, the regression parameter is estimated on the robustfit function in MATLAB [55]. For setup GLM, the regression parameter is estimated based on the robust GLM estimation method [56] that uses observation-specific dummy variables and penalization. For setup MVN, Ω∗−1superscriptsubscriptΩ1\Omega_{*}^{-1} is estimated according to the robustcov function in MATLAB [55] which implements the minimum covariance determinant estimator in [57]. (IV) EM, EMH, EML, EMB. Algorithm 1 using uniform, Hamming, local shuffling, and block-Hamming prior, respectively, where the latter three reflect the constraint sets (i) to (iii) in (15). The EM iterations are initialized by setting π=id𝜋id\pi=\textsf{id}, and the number of EM iterations is limited to 400. The number of MCMC iterations per EM iteration is set to 8k, half of which are counted towards the “burn-in period”. We note that a modified MH algorithm is used for EML (cf. Appendix F); for EMB, the MH scheme in Algorithm 2 is applied block by block. For the Sparse and SparseBlock settings, the hyperparameter γ𝛾\gamma is chosen based on Proposition 1, which suggests γ∝log⁡(n)proportional-to𝛾𝑛\gamma\propto\log(n). For the Banded setting, the choice γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 was found to yield good performance. (V) Lahiri & Larsen (LL), Chambers (C) [for setting k𝑘k-SparseBlock only]. The approaches described in [28] and [47] with the choice Q=𝐄⁡[Π∗]=IB⊗Q0𝑄𝐄superscriptΠtensor-productsubscript𝐼𝐵subscript𝑄0Q=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\Pi^{*}]=I_{B}\otimes Q_{0}, where Q0=(1−α∗)​In/B+α∗​𝟏n/B​𝟏n/B⊤subscript𝑄01subscript𝛼subscript𝐼𝑛𝐵subscript𝛼subscript1𝑛𝐵superscriptsubscript1𝑛𝐵topQ_{0}=(1-\alpha_{*})I_{n/B}+\alpha_{*}\mathbf{1}_{n/B}\mathbf{1}_{n/B}^{\top}, α∗=(k⋅B)/nsubscript𝛼⋅𝑘𝐵𝑛\alpha_{*}=(k\cdot B)/n. For setup MVN, the LL approach amounts to estimation of Ω∗subscriptΩ\Omega_{*} by the inverse of the modified sample covariance matrix S~~𝑆\widetilde{S} with blocks S~𝐱𝐱=𝐗⊤​𝐗/nsubscript~𝑆𝐱𝐱superscript𝐗top𝐗𝑛\widetilde{S}_{\mathbf{x}\mathbf{x}}=\mathbf{X}^{\top}\mathbf{X}/n, S~𝐱𝐲=𝐗⊤​Q⊤​𝐘/nsubscript~𝑆𝐱𝐲superscript𝐗topsuperscript𝑄top𝐘𝑛\widetilde{S}_{\mathbf{x}\mathbf{y}}=\mathbf{X}^{\top}Q^{\top}\mathbf{Y}/n, and S~𝐲𝐲=𝐘⊤​𝐘/nsubscript~𝑆𝐲𝐲superscript𝐘top𝐘𝑛\widetilde{S}_{\mathbf{y}\mathbf{y}}=\mathbf{Y}^{\top}\mathbf{Y}/n.

(VI) Averaging [for setting r𝑟r-Banded only]. We compute (componentwise) running averages of the {𝐱i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and {𝐲i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{\mathbf{y}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} within sliding windows of size r𝑟r, and estimate the parameters β∗superscript𝛽\beta^{*} and Ω∗subscriptΩ\Omega_{*} from these local averages in the usual way (i.e., if these were the original and uncontaminated data).

For better comparison across different experimental configurations, we visualize the relative estimation error (REE) ∥βest−β∗∥2/∥β∗∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽estsuperscript𝛽2subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽2\lVert\beta^{\text{est}}-\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}/\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} and ∥Correst−Corr∗∥Fsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptCorrestsuperscriptCorrF\lVert\text{Corr}^{\text{est}}-\text{Corr}^{*}\rVert_{\textsf{F}} , where βestsuperscript𝛽est\beta^{\text{est}} and CorrestsuperscriptCorrest\text{Corr}^{\text{est}} are a placeholder for the aforementioned estimators; Corr refers to the correlation matrix corresponding to Ω∗−1superscriptsubscriptΩ1\Omega_{*}^{-1}. Selected results are shown in Figure 3, which displays averages of the REE over 100 replications for each model and each permutation. Real data. We consider seven benchmark data sets for shuffled data problems as tabulated in Table 1. The data sets are preprocessed versions of their original counterparts. Even though the data sets themselves are real, the permutations that scramble the given matching pairs {(𝐱i,𝐲i)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{n} are synthetic. We consider the same list of competitors and associated configurations as for the synthetic data experiments. Asterisked ground truth parameters here refer to oracle estimates based on knowledge of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}, and relative estimation error (REE) is defined accordingly in terms of those (pseudo)-ground truth parameters.

Hamming and Block prior. As can be seen from Figure 4, the proposed approach consistently improves over naive least squares once the fraction of mismatches exceeds 0.2, and yields significant improvements as that fraction increases. The regularized EM approach with specific prior (i.e. EMB, EMH, EML) noticeable reduces error induced by shuffling.

Local shuffling prior. As shown in the Table 2, the EM approach with local shuffling prior achieves significant error reductions compared to the naive approach and the EM approach without regularization.

Data Augmentation

In this paragraph we present a brief illustration of the proposed approach when used in conjunction with data augmentation, i.e., both the parameter and the permutation are sampled in an alternating fashion (cf. discussion at the end of §§\S2.3). For this purpose, we consider the Italian household survey discussed in [58], see also Table 1. This data set involves a simple linear regression problem in which the household income (in 1k Euros) in 2010 is is regressed on the same quantity in 2008, including an intercept term.

The process of file linkage subject to mismatch error involving the income data from the two years under consideration is simulated by generating a permutation π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} uniformly at random from the Hamming ball of radius k𝑘k around the identity permutation, where k/n=0.4𝑘𝑛0.4k/n=0.4.

Following the paradigm of data augmentation in [50] in which π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*} is considered as missing data yields the following scheme that alternates between sampling of a permutation π𝜋\pi and sampling of regression parameters β=(β0,β1)𝛽subscript𝛽0subscript𝛽1\beta=(\beta_{0},\beta_{1}) and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} given responses 𝐘=(yi)i=1n𝐘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathbf{Y}=(y_{i})_{i=1}^{n} (income from 2010) and design matrix 𝐗=[𝟏n​(xi)i=1n]𝐗delimited-[]subscript1𝑛superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathbf{X}=[\bm{1}_{n}\;(x_{i})_{i=1}^{n}] (intercept and income from 2008).

(II) Posterior Step: (a) Sample ​β(k)​from​1m​∑j=1mp​(β|σ2(k−1),π(j),𝐘,𝐗),(a) Sample superscript𝛽𝑘from1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚𝑝conditional𝛽superscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑘1superscript𝜋𝑗𝐘𝐗\displaystyle\text{(a) Sample }\beta^{(k)}\;\text{from}\;\,\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}p(\beta|{\sigma^{2}}^{(k-1)},\pi^{(j)},\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X}),
(b) Sample​σ2(k)​ from ​1m​∑j=1mp​(σ2|β(k),π(j),𝐘,𝐗),(b) Samplesuperscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑘 from 1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝛽𝑘superscript𝜋𝑗𝐘𝐗\displaystyle\text{(b) Sample}\;{\sigma^{2}}^{(k)}\text{ from }\;\,\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}p(\sigma^{2}|\beta^{(k)},\pi^{(j)},\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X}),

where m𝑚m denotes the number of samples in the augmentation step, and k𝑘k denotes the iteration counter for the parameters (β,σ2)𝛽superscript𝜎2(\beta,\sigma^{2}).

Sampling in step (I) is implemented according to the MH procedure shown in Algorithm 2. Furthermore, under the usual non-informative prior distribution for (β,σ2)𝛽superscript𝜎2(\beta,\sigma^{2}), i.e., p​(β,σ2)∝σ−2proportional-to𝑝𝛽superscript𝜎2superscript𝜎2p(\beta,\sigma^{2})\propto\sigma^{-2}, the full conditonal distributions appearing in step (II) are given by

β~:=(𝐗⊤𝐗)−1𝐗⊤Π⊤𝐘,s2:=1n−d∥𝐘−Π𝐗β~∥22,\displaystyle\widetilde{\beta}\mathrel{\mathop{:}}=(\mathbf{X}^{\top}\mathbf{X})^{-1}\mathbf{X}^{\top}\Pi^{\top}\mathbf{Y},\quad s^{2}\mathrel{\mathop{:}}=\frac{1}{n-d}\lVert\mathbf{Y}-\Pi\mathbf{X}\widetilde{\beta}\rVert_{2}^{2},

where Inv-​χ2​(ν,a2)Inv-superscript𝜒2𝜈superscript𝑎2\text{Inv-}\chi^{2}(\nu,a^{2}) refers to the scaled inverse χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}-distribution with scale parameter a>0𝑎0a>0 and ν𝜈\nu degrees of freedom (cf. §§\S14 in [52] for more details on Bayesian inference for linear regression models).

For this illustration, we use m=100𝑚100m=100, where each sequence {π(j)}superscript𝜋𝑗\{\pi^{(j)}\} is generated by uniform thinning of Markov chains of length 4,00040004,000 generated by Algorithm 2. The number of samples (β(k),σ2(k))superscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑘(\beta^{(k)},{\sigma^{2}}^{(k)}) obtained via the above scheme is taken as 1,000. The sampling procedure is initialized from step (II) with the identity permutation. We compare both the unregularized case with the uniform prior for π𝜋\pi as well as the regularized case with the Hamming prior (8) (γ=log⁡n𝛾𝑛\gamma=\log n in view of Proposition 1).

Figure 5 confirms that the proposed approach achieves visible improvements over the unregularized approach which suffers from serious amplification bias affecting the slope parameter β1subscript𝛽1\beta_{1} and serious underestimation of the error variance, as predicted by the brief analysis accompanying the first introductory example in §§\S2.1.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a framework for regularized estimation in shuffled data problems by means of an exponential family prior on the permutation group. As elaborated above, the exponential family form is convenient for computational purposes yet sufficiently rich to incorporate various common forms of prior knowledge. In particular, the prior is not tailored to specific data analysis problems, but can be applied generically. The results in this paper confirm the importance of regularization in shuffled data problems given the inherent danger of overfitting already in the presence of little noise. While the approach covers a variety of constraints that can be imposed on the underlying permutation, it is certainly not exhaustive: not all sorts of prior knowledge can be captured via the prior proposed herein. For example, suppose we have information on the cycles of the permutation (numbers and/or lengths). Such information cannot be expressed in terms of index pairs, and hence requires a different paradigm. Several authors [59, 60] have considered the Fourier analysis on the permutation group [43] to facilitate learning problems involving permutations, and it is an interesting direction of future research to study how that approach can be leveraged for the type of shuffled data problems considered in the present paper. Moreover, we herein have focused on the situation where exactly two files are merged. It is of interest to consider more complex situations arising from linkage of several files and multiple permutations as well as the modeling of potential dependencies among those: for examples, the permutations might be completely unrelated, or identical [25, 61], or involve intermediate situations with varying degrees of overlap.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 1

In light of relation (10), straightforward manipulations and omission of terms not depending on ΠΠ\Pi show that the MAP estimator Π^^Π\widehat{\Pi} is the minimizer of the optimization problem

minΠ∈𝒫​(n)⁡{−⟨𝐘,Π​𝝁⟩+σ∗2​γ​dH​(Π,In)}.subscriptΠ𝒫𝑛𝐘Π𝝁superscriptsubscript𝜎2𝛾subscript𝑑HΠsubscript𝐼𝑛\min_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\left\{-\left\langle\mathbf{Y},\Pi\bm{\mu}\right\rangle+\sigma_{*}^{2}\gamma d_{\textsf{H}}(\Pi,I_{n})\right\}. (17)

Since Π^^Π\widehat{\Pi} minimizes (17), the following basic inequality holds true:

−⟨𝐘,Π^​𝝁⟩+σ∗2​γ​dH​(Π^,In)≤−⟨𝐘,Π∗​𝝁⟩+σ∗2​γ​dH​(Π∗,In)𝐘^Π𝝁superscriptsubscript𝜎2𝛾subscript𝑑H^Πsubscript𝐼𝑛𝐘superscriptΠ𝝁superscriptsubscript𝜎2𝛾subscript𝑑HsuperscriptΠsubscript𝐼𝑛-\langle\mathbf{Y},\widehat{\Pi}\bm{\mu}\rangle+\sigma_{*}^{2}\gamma d_{\textsf{H}}(\widehat{\Pi},I_{n})\leq-\langle\mathbf{Y},\Pi^{*}\bm{\mu}\rangle+\sigma_{*}^{2}\gamma d_{\textsf{H}}(\Pi^{*},I_{n}) (18)

Decomposing 𝐘=𝝁+𝝃𝐘𝝁𝝃\mathbf{Y}=\bm{\mu}+\bm{\xi} with 𝝃=σ∗​ϵ𝝃subscript𝜎bold-italic-ϵ\bm{\xi}=\sigma_{*}\bm{\epsilon} and re-arranging terms in the above inequality yields that

⟨Π∗​𝝁,(Π∗−Π^)​𝝁⟩−⟨𝝃,(Π^−Π∗)​𝝁⟩+σ∗2​γ​dH​(Π^,In)≤σ∗2​γ​k,superscriptΠ𝝁superscriptΠ^Π𝝁𝝃^ΠsuperscriptΠ𝝁superscriptsubscript𝜎2𝛾subscript𝑑H^Πsubscript𝐼𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜎2𝛾𝑘\langle\Pi^{*}\bm{\mu},(\Pi^{*}-\widehat{\Pi})\bm{\mu}\rangle-\langle\bm{\xi},(\widehat{\Pi}-\Pi^{*})\bm{\mu}\rangle+\sigma_{*}^{2}\gamma d_{\textsf{H}}(\widehat{\Pi},I_{n})\leq\sigma_{*}^{2}\gamma k,

where we have substituted dH​(Π∗,In)=ksubscript𝑑HsuperscriptΠsubscript𝐼𝑛𝑘d_{\textsf{H}}(\Pi^{*},I_{n})=k. Appendix C Proof of Proposition 1

The probability mass function of (8) is given by [44]:

p(π)=exp⁡(−γ​dH​(π,id))ψ​(γ),ψ(γ):=n!exp(−γn)∑k=0n(exp⁡(γ)−1)kk!.p(\pi)=\frac{\exp(-\gamma d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id}))}{\psi(\gamma)},\qquad\psi(\gamma)\mathrel{\mathop{:}}=n!\exp(-\gamma n)\sum^{n}_{k=0}\frac{(\exp(\gamma)-1)^{k}}{k!}. (22)

In the sequel, let us write {D​(π)=d}𝐷𝜋𝑑\{D(\pi)=d\} as a shortcut for the event {dH​(π,id)=d}subscript𝑑H𝜋id𝑑\{d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi,\textsf{id})=d\}. We then have

where !d!d denotes the number of derangements of {1,…,d}1…𝑑\{1,\ldots,d\}, i.e., the number of permutations τ𝜏\tau of d𝑑d objects such that τ​(j)≠j𝜏𝑗𝑗\tau(j)\neq j for all 1≤j≤d1𝑗𝑑1\leq j\leq d. Straightforward manipulations yield

𝐏⁡(D​(π)≥k)=∑d=knexp⁡(−γ​d)​n!d!​(n−d)!!​dn!​exp⁡(−γ​n)​∑ℓ=0n(exp⁡(γ)−1)ℓℓ!=∑d=knexp⁡(γ​(n−d))(n−d)!​∑ℓ=0n(exp⁡(γ)−1)ℓℓ!​!dd!.\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbf{P}}(D(\pi)\geq k)=\sum^{n}_{d=k}\frac{\exp(-\gamma d)\frac{n!}{d!(n-d)!}!d}{n!\exp(-\gamma n)\sum^{n}_{\ell=0}\frac{(\exp(\gamma)-1)^{\ell}}{\ell!}}=\sum^{n}_{d=k}\frac{\exp(\gamma(n-d))}{(n-d)!\sum^{n}_{\ell=0}\frac{(\exp(\gamma)-1)^{\ell}}{\ell!}}\frac{!d}{d!}. (23)

For x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0 and integer m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1, define the (upper) incomplete Gamma function and its “normalized” counterpart by

Γ​(m,x)=∫x∞tn−1​e−t​𝑑t,Γ~​(m,x)=Γ​(m,x)/Γ​(m),formulae-sequenceΓ𝑚𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑥superscript𝑡𝑛1superscript𝑒𝑡differential-d𝑡~Γ𝑚𝑥Γ𝑚𝑥Γ𝑚\Gamma(m,x)=\int^{\infty}_{x}t^{n-1}e^{-t}\,dt,\qquad\widetilde{\Gamma}(m,x)=\Gamma(m,x)/\Gamma(m),

where Γ​(m)=Γ​(m,0)=(m−1)!Γ𝑚Γ𝑚0𝑚1\Gamma(m)=\Gamma(m,0)=(m-1)! denotes the Gamma function. It can be shown that [65, §§\S6.5]

provided γ≥(1+δ)​log⁡n𝛾1𝛿𝑛\gamma\geq(1+\delta)\log n, which concludes the proof of the upper bound.

Regarding the lower bound, observe that in view of relation (24), the ratio of normalized incomplete Gamma functions can be expressed via the ratio of CDFs of two independent Poisson random variables, that is

Γ~​(n−k+1,exp⁡(γ))Γ~​(n+1,exp⁡(γ)−1)=𝐏⁡(X1≤n−k)𝐏⁡(X2≤n),~Γ𝑛𝑘1𝛾~Γ𝑛1𝛾1𝐏subscript𝑋1𝑛𝑘𝐏subscript𝑋2𝑛\frac{\widetilde{\Gamma}(n-k+1,\exp(\gamma))}{\widetilde{\Gamma}(n+1,\exp(\gamma)-1)}=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbf{P}}(X_{1}\leq n-k)}{\operatorname{\mathbf{P}}(X_{2}\leq n)},

where X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} and X2subscript𝑋2X_{2} are two independent Poisson random variables with parameters exp⁡(γ)𝛾\exp(\gamma) and exp⁡(γ)−1𝛾1\exp(\gamma)-1, respectively. Setting γ=log⁡(n−k)𝛾𝑛𝑘\gamma=\log(n-k) yields that the right hand side is a function of the form c1​(n,k)subscript𝑐1𝑛𝑘c_{1}(n,k) that is lower and upper bounded by 1/4141/4 and 111, respectively, as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Taking c​(k,n)=c0​(k,n)⋅c1​(k,n)𝑐𝑘𝑛⋅subscript𝑐0𝑘𝑛subscript𝑐1𝑘𝑛c(k,n)=c_{0}(k,n)\cdot c_{1}(k,n) yields the assertion.

Similar to Eq. (18) in the proof of Theorem 1, we have the basic inequality

The “in particular” part of the statement then follows immediately from the triangle inequality and the Lipschitz property.

Appendix E Integrated maximum likelihood estimator and overfitting

In this section, it is briefly explained that under a uniform prior p​(π)∝1proportional-to𝑝𝜋1p(\pi)\propto 1, the integrated maximum likelihood estimator based on (11) still exhibits a tendency to overfit, in a spirit similar to what is shown in §§\S2.1 for the maximum likelihood estimator of π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}. To demonstrate this point, we consider the following setup:

𝐘|𝐗,Π,β,σ∗2∼N​(Π​𝐗​β,σ∗2),p​(Π)∝1,p​(β)∝1,formulae-sequencesimilar-toconditional𝐘𝐗Π𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜎2𝑁Π𝐗𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜎2formulae-sequenceproportional-to𝑝Π1proportional-to𝑝𝛽1\displaystyle\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X},\Pi,\beta,\sigma_{*}^{2}\sim N(\Pi\mathbf{X}\beta,\sigma_{*}^{2}),\qquad p(\Pi)\propto 1,\quad p(\beta)\propto 1, (28)

and σ∗2>0superscriptsubscript𝜎20\sigma_{*}^{2}>0 fixed. The integrated likelihood corresponding to (11) is then given by

L​(β)=p​(𝒟|β)=∫p​(𝒟|π,β)​p​(π|β)​𝑑π=∫p​(π,β|𝒟)​p​(𝒟)p​(π|β)​p​(β)​p​(π|β)​𝑑π∝∫p​(β|π,𝒟)​p​(π|𝒟)​𝑑π.𝐿𝛽𝑝conditional𝒟𝛽𝑝conditional𝒟𝜋𝛽𝑝conditional𝜋𝛽differential-d𝜋𝑝𝜋conditional𝛽𝒟𝑝𝒟𝑝conditional𝜋𝛽𝑝𝛽𝑝conditional𝜋𝛽differential-d𝜋proportional-to𝑝conditional𝛽𝜋𝒟𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟differential-d𝜋\displaystyle L(\beta)=p(\mathcal{D}|\beta)=\int p(\mathcal{D}|\pi,\beta)p(\pi|\beta)\,d\pi=\int\frac{p(\pi,\beta|\mathcal{D})p(\mathcal{D})}{p(\pi|\beta)p(\beta)}p(\pi|\beta)\,d\pi\propto\int p(\beta|\pi,\mathcal{D})p(\pi|\mathcal{D})\,d\pi.

Observe that under (28)

p​(β|π,𝒟)∼N​((𝐗T​𝐗)−1​𝐗⊤​Π​𝐗​β∗,σ∗2​(𝐗⊤​𝐗)−1),p​(π|𝒟)∝exp⁡(−∥PΠ​𝐗⟂​𝐘∥222​σ∗2),formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑝conditional𝛽𝜋𝒟𝑁superscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑇𝐗1superscript𝐗topΠ𝐗superscript𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜎2superscriptsuperscript𝐗top𝐗1proportional-to𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptPΠ𝐗perpendicular-to𝐘222superscriptsubscript𝜎2p(\beta|\pi,\mathcal{D})\sim N((\mathbf{X}^{T}\mathbf{X})^{-1}\mathbf{X}^{\top}\Pi\mathbf{X}\beta^{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}(\mathbf{X}^{\top}\mathbf{X})^{-1}),\qquad p(\pi|\mathcal{D})\propto\exp\left(-\frac{\lVert\texttt{P}_{\Pi\mathbf{X}}^{\perp}\mathbf{Y}\rVert_{2}^{2}}{2\sigma_{*}^{2}}\right),

where PΠ​𝐗⟂superscriptsubscriptPΠ𝐗perpendicular-to\texttt{P}_{\Pi\mathbf{X}}^{\perp} denotes the projection on the orthogonal complement of the column space of Π​𝐗Π𝐗\Pi\mathbf{X}. Note that p​(π|𝒟)𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟p(\pi|\mathcal{D}) is high for permutations achieving good fit (overfit) to the data, and the optimization problem maxβ⁡p​(𝒟|β)subscript𝛽𝑝conditional𝒟𝛽\max_{\beta}p(\mathcal{D}|\beta) will be dominated by the modes of those distributions p​(β|π,𝒟)𝑝conditional𝛽𝜋𝒟p(\beta|\pi,\mathcal{D}) for which the corresponding weight p​(π|𝒟)𝑝conditional𝜋𝒟p(\pi|\mathcal{D}) is high. In particular, in regimes with SNR=∥β∗∥22/σ∗2SNRsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝛽22superscriptsubscript𝜎2\textsf{SNR}=\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}^{2}/\sigma_{*}^{2} large, the maximizer of the integrated likelihood will not substantially differ from the estimator returned by maxπ,β⁡p​(𝒟|β,π)subscript𝜋𝛽𝑝conditional𝒟𝛽𝜋\max_{\pi,\beta}p(\mathcal{D}|\beta,\pi) (the MLE in §§\S2.1), which is known to overfit dramatically.
